body:
Alternative to https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24538

The next version of cython is going to change the default to '3str', may be worth applying the pinning to bug-fix branches?

Thanks for the PR! Unfortunately we are dropping Python2 support in the 0.25 release so I don't think pinning to that syntax here makes sense. Should be going forward with the PR you've linked to in the near future
IIUC, this would allow people to compile pandas 0.24.x from source with future versions of Cython? Any reason not to do that for now?

@TomAugspurger makes sense. I was thinking originally it would be nice to not have to pin anything and implicitly get everything onto Py3 with next release, but suppose it doesn't hurt to have this pinned for 0.24.x

Just to be clear, I'm don't *know* that that's a benefit of pinning it for
now, before your proper fix is ready. That was more of a question :)

On Mon, Feb 4, 2019 at 3:54 PM William Ayd <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *@WillAyd* requested changes on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In setup.py
> <https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/25145#discussion_r253661445>:
>
> > @@ -472,6 +472,7 @@ def maybe_cythonize(extensions, *args, **kwargs):
>      """
>      Render tempita templates before calling cythonize
>      """
> +    kwargs.setdefault('language_level', 2)
>
> There is a dict in this file which contains directives sent to cythonize.
> Think it would be more consistent if you set this therein (see PR you
> linked for sample of how)
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/25145#pullrequestreview-199826446>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABQHInSagdfPuQAoEu3BlzbZ2SJo260Uks5vKKwrgaJpZM4ahrg3>
> .
>

@tacaswell where do you see the note about 3str becoming the default on next release? Also, does that actually impact compilation? IIRC there was only one spot in the code base that was really problematic for 2-to-3 comparability and it was the result of unicode usage, which I would think 3str would still respect?

https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/changes.html?highlight=3str#id7 for "3str" becoming the default in the future.

Empirically, pandas does not cythonize/compile properly without this patch with cython master.

This is setting the dialect of cython (not the version of python) so you can use any of the language levels (2, 3, 3str) with any version of python (as it generates c-extensions that then have the correct bindings to the calling python) so I think this is un-related to deciding to drop py2 support.  I think you should back port this to any version of pandas you want people to be able to compile with future versions of cython that you do not want to backport #24538 to.
But Python 2.7 is not yet dropped from 0.24.x. So as @tacaswell said it might make sense to apply this patch for that reason?

Yea understood about how it's technically different from our Python support level, though we theoretically want to be consistent in how we write code.

IIRC the original Cython warning would mention a push to `3` syntax in the future but if that is now `3str` I'm under the impression our code on 0.24 is already compatible with that syntax, hence why I don't think we need to pin anything here. Are you seeing errors building with `3str`?
Sorry, ignore my previous comment, my github notifications were lagging seriously behind. @TomAugspurger already noticed the same

pandas master + cython master:

Ah OK division is where this gets tripped up. Thanks for confirming I’d be ok with the pin here then

not sure I understand why we need this change? to prevent source building on later cythons? we could just as easily (maybe better) put a max on cython if PY2 in setup.py (like we have a min now).

Its probably easier for us and users to set this value than to put a max version on Cython. Either should work though.

I slightly prefer this to code in setup because:

1. I think it's less verbose AND
2. I don't see an indication that 2 syntax gets dropped in the next Cython, only that the default changes

So given point 2 above I don't see a reason to necessarily cap the Cython dependency.

Not a huge sticking point for me either way though
